channel.title: Am I being scammed?
channel.description: I recently got a message on discord by someone claiming that they own a website that helps you get "views". Not to mention he has very bad English. I’m not a big fan of these types of sites because I like getting natural plays. So is it a scam or not ![image|445x500](upload://bIL7zPsikeiA5Q7yY747YTBo6fI.jpeg)

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
99% chance that it’s fake and won’t contribute to much (if any) exposure increase.
1% chance that there’s some vaguely legitimate aspect of it but it’s behind a paywall.

Refer to this thread for more information about common signs of services / promotions to stay away from.

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Arimyth:

You claim to understand the points I’m raising, but the rest of your response would suggest otherwise.

:sigh: I could make the exact same remark about your ‘non-dismissal’ of the OP’s question.

Your point isn’t complex. (Maybe we have some crossed-wires going on.)

We simply seem to disagree about how much detail in general, and what key detail in particular, is required to understand the offer and make an informed decision about it.

We also seem to disagree a little about what constitutes a categorical deal-breaker.

If that’s not the meat of your point, I’m genuinely interested to understand. I’m always open to the idea that I might be wrong.

 

whether or not it is a “scam” as in you will be swindled out of something is perhaps a different question

Funny, given that’s the OP’s original question, It’s not a different question. It’s the question.

 

verify the safety

I’d be interested to hear what you believe is ‘unsafe’ about this free offer.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
Seems like the conversation isn’t really getting anywhere. You claim to understand the points I’m raising, but the rest of your response would suggest otherwise. I’ll put the main conclusion below, in a concise summary.

RocketYou is a new crowdfunding / sponsoring site, which appears to have traces of legitimacy, but the time you’ll have to take to verify the safety of this method compared to the potential benefit is not worth it. There are several signs that the site is illegitimate (whether or not it is a “scam” as in you will be swindled out of something is perhaps a different question). Feel free to look into the company as it very well may be atleast somewhat legitimate, but until someone does, it is safe to say that it should be stayed away from for the time being.

And with that, I’d call it a day.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
With that said, feel free to take it to a DM if you wish to discuss this further. No need to take up OP’s entire thread

Curious. If it was such a concern for you, why not send your last reply as a PM?

 
For the record…

Do I believe it’s a scam? No.

Do I recommend using/trying the service? No.

Do I believe there’s a risk to trying the service? No.

Do I think that RocketYou is making several potentially catastrophic missteps? Yes.

(Fwiw, I’ve helped launch large platform betas. So I understand that it’s not easy building market confidence in a brand new offering, especially one that challenges the dominant model.)

 

The rest… (click for more details)

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
At this point I’m wondering if you work for RocketYou.

akabillposters:

Lack of reviews doesn’t in itself mean an offer is or isn’t legit or a scam. It just means it’s early days, so you’ll have to judge for yourself. (It’s far better to do this once you’ve developed an understanding of what’s actually being offered - and the implications for oneself.)

Which is why I substantiated my deduction that it is lacks credibility with other evidence besides its reviews (or lack thereof).

akabillposters:

I’ve not seen anyone here ‘naively accepting’ such messages or recommending that others do that. I’ve certainly done neither of those things.

Perhaps a poor choice of words. The OP of this thread is obviously questioning the legitimacy of this service (as he should be) so I’m supplying him with a list of methods that he can utilize to make the decision on his own.

akabillposters:

I’m sure you don’t know enough about how “real, well known promotional agencies” handle sales and marketing to make that kind of generalisation.

You don’t need to be a full time professional in the music industry to understand and recognize a good business model. And this isn’t one. It fails on perhaps the most crucial step, which is selling the idea. The fact that it even looks like a scam should be a red flag.

akabillposters:

It’s lucky you’re here to remind the OP that their question isn’t important (or relevant).

Missing the point again. I’m not saying OP’s question is irrelevant. What I am saying is less relevant is your need to hash out the exact details of RocketYou’s offer. From what I can see, the people on this thread understand it well enough to make an informed decision without getting hindered by unnecessary details.

akabillposters:

If by “your definition” you mean the dictionary definition then surely you can see there could be a problem for a productive conversation if some are rolling with their own different interpretations of words.

If you want to get technical about it:
scam: noun - informal: a dishonest scheme; a fraud.
Since you don’t have any more experience with RocketYou than anybody else here, it might be beneficial to leave the debating about what exactly the dictionary definition of what a scam is for another time. It’s besides the point, and any of the definitions raised in this thread will suffice.

akabillposters:

…said no innovator, ever.

There’s a difference between being cavalier and overly confident, and using new technologies to ones advantage. Make sure you know which one you’re doing.

Note: With that said, feel free to take it to a DM if you wish to discuss this further. No need to take up OP’s entire thread with walls of text that don’t contribute to a straightforward and decisive answer for him (or others) to base a decision off of.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Arimyth:

You continue to miss the point being raised, which is that the “spokesperson” of this service acts highly unprofessionally, the company itself doesn’t appear to have (a notable amount of) reviews, and going down the track of naively accepting randomly messaged promotional offerings can be dangerous.

:sigh: OK…

  1. I’ve not missed any points. I’ve acknowledged the poor English and was first to try to explain (not justify or excuse) how it happened. I’m on record as saying it’s a poor marketing decision.
  2. Lack of reviews doesn’t in itself mean an offer is or isn’t legit or a scam. It just means it’s early days, so you’ll have to judge for yourself. (It’s far better to do this once you’ve developed an understanding of what’s actually being offered - and the implications for oneself.)
  3. I’ve not seen anyone here ‘naively accepting’ such messages or recommending that others do that. I’ve certainly done neither of those things.

 

I’m sure you know that real, well known promotional agencies don’t DM people on discord in a bot-like fashion offering up their “services”

I’m sure you don’t know enough about how “real, well known promotional agencies” handle sales and marketing to make that kind of generalisation.

Fwiw, I work within marketing and I know enough not to make generalisations like that.

It’s highly likely that companies offering music services, such as promoters and even label A&Rs, are hanging out where music makers hang out. Discord servers are increasingly part of that landscape.

Similarly, it’s likely that an increasing number of meaningful transactions start out as DMs on obscure music communities.

Years ago we’d question the legitimacy and reputation of companies who used Twitter to handle customer support requests. But, it’s pretty common now. Go figure.

The exact, specific offer that RocketYou proposes isn’t important.

It’s lucky you’re here to remind the OP that their question isn’t important (or relevant).

It’s fine if you want to rail against bot offers etc… (I’m no fan either), but at least attempt to properly address the OP’s question first (and know the difference), rather than attempting to second-guess their ‘actual’ question. What you refer to as the “real point” simply appears to be the point you feel should be discussed.

It’s related, but it’s not the OP’s question. So, first things first maybe.

Arimyth:

Putting aside the fact that other peoples’ definition of a scam doesn’t exactly match your definition word for word

If by “your definition” you mean the dictionary definition then surely you can see there could be a problem for a productive conversation if some are rolling with their own different interpretations of words.

If someone doesn’t first clarify that they’re using a non-standard definition, I tend to assume we’re all using the same standard definition. Communication tends to work better that way.

 

avoid newer methods

…said no innovator, ever.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
You continue to miss the point being raised, which is that the “spokesperson” of this service acts highly unprofessionally, the company itself doesn’t appear to have (a notable amount of) reviews, and going down the track of naively accepting randomly messaged promotional offerings can be dangerous.

I’m sure you know that real, well known promotional agencies don’t DM people on discord in a bot-like fashion offering up their “services”. The exact, specific offer that RocketYou proposes isn’t important. Putting aside the fact that other peoples’ definition of a scam doesn’t exactly match your definition word for word, having done some looking into the company I can say that it looks fishy at the very least.

tl;dr Stick to well known promotional agencies and distribution platforms, and self promotion, but avoid newer methods such as RocketYou and others, atleast until they build more of a reputation.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Arimyth:

I suggest that we don’t get caught up in debating the definition of “a scam” or “shadiness” / telling people that they don’t know what they’re talking about / debating the quantity of said plays that are being offered. It can be confusing and obfuscate the real point that the original poster / anyone who has this question needs to take into account.

I don’t know how it’s possible to accurately and reasonably address ‘the real point’ without…

  1. First knowing what constitutes a scam.
  2. Having the ability to discern between this offer and other offers

Better to leave this question to people who are willing to look a bit deeper and/or who have more knowledge on the subject. Certainly better than spouting uninformed opinion as though it were fact (as some have done here) and making potentially libellous statements with no foundation. That doesn’t help anyone.

But, hey, that’s just my opinion.

 
Given the rest of your response, I think you’re amongst those who haven’t properly grasped what RocketYou is offering either. (I’m not saying that it’s a good offer, but it’s worth having a decent understanding of what the offer actually is, if you’re going to pass judgement on it and advise others about it.)

They’re not selling batches of empty plays, so directly comparing it to ‘promo channels’ offering X plays/like/reposts for $10 isn’t as helpful as you might think.

If you believe I’ve misunderstood RocketYou’s offer, then I’m happy for you to correct me and point out how.

I’d also appreciate those who are convinced it’s a scam explaining to me how the scam supposedly works - keeping in mind that the offering is free to artists.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
akabillposters:

Afaik, it’s still not clear if YT is making a decent profit as a company yet.

It’s not at least at the last time I heard it. Google Apparently still isn’t making revenue. The adpocolypse certainly didn’t help that.

Read full topic

item.title: Am I being scammed?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
I suggest that we don’t get caught up in debating the definition of “a scam” or “shadiness” / telling people that they don’t know what they’re talking about / debating the quantity of said plays that are being offered. It can be confusing and obfuscate the real point that the original poster / anyone who has this question needs to take into account.

@HELIXX Regardless of the legitimacy of this offer, plays in mass quantity rarely if ever help your publicity or help you expand. In fact, they can often hurt your profile, as the plays are mainly from “listeners” that will not be repeat listeners / don’t actually care about your music that much. Not to mention that a track with a ton of plays but almost no comments / feedback or real interaction looks odd to an outsider.

Therefore, it’s best to ignore these types of offers, as while this may be legitimate at least in some respects, other offers are not and will try to scam you or require payment. Real, interested listeners are the best and the only reliable way to improve upon your musical persona.

Read full topic
